para.paratext: Experts cannot testify about the truthfulness of a witness,[1] but can testify about the ability of children of a certain age to distinguish truth from falsity, and whether medical, or other objective evidence, is consistent with a minor victim's testimony.[2] Thus, in Hall v. State[3] the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed a conviction in a child molestation case because the trial court excluded testimony that the victim had not exhibited the “unusual and inappropriate behavior” typical of a sexually abused child. The court noted that the testimony was not offered on the issue of whether the child had been molested and that the “typical” behavior of a sexually abused child is not within the ken of the average juror. The Court of Appeals has further held that an expert may testify regarding indications of a witness's resistance to suggestibility.[4] In another case, the Court of Appeals also found it proper for a forensic interviewer to opine regarding similarities between two statements given by a victim. The court noted that the interviewer merely indicated that the victim was consistent in her story, but offered no opinion on the veracity of the victim.[5] An expert witness' opinion testimony that a victim was telling the truth, however, constitutes improper bolstering because the inference to be drawn is not beyond the ken of the average juror.[6]

In Jennett v. State,[7] the court upheld the trial court's exclusion of expert opinion testimony about the “lying child syndrome,” which explains the propensity of children to relate to and repeat untruthful statements about a person in a position of authority, in a battery trial against a Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC) instructor charged with sexually assaulting and battering several students. The court stated that the jury could evaluate the credibility of the students who made the accusations and that this was not a “unique and mysterious area” of the type that required expert opinion testimony.

In Lott v. State,[8] the court reversed a child molestation conviction because the trial court admitted opinion testimony from the investigating officer that most wives sided with their husbands in child molestation cases. The court found that the investigator was not an expert and the testimony was not beyond the ken of average jurors. The same year, the court held that expert opinion testimony about whether a child molestation defendant is a pedophile is inadmissible[9]
Smith v. State, 259 Ga. 135, 377 S.E.2d 158 (1989) (overruled on other grounds by, State v. Burns, 829 S.E.2d 367 (Ga. 2019)).
However, lay opinion testimony regarding a witness's character for truthfulness is now admissible in certain circumstances. See O.C.G.A. § 24-6-608.
